def_en: A quarter is one of four equal parts of something.
A quarter is a fixed period of three months. Companies often divide their financial year into four quarters.

When you are telling the time, you use quarter to talk about the fifteen minutes before or after an hour. For example, 8.15 is quarter past eight, and 8.45 is quarter to nine. In American English, you can also say that 8.15 is a quarter after eight and 8.45 is a quarter of nine.
If you quarter something such as a fruit or a vegetable, you cut it into four roughly equal parts.

def_cn: 把…降至原先的四分之一;把…减少四分之三
def_en: If the number or size of something is quartered, it is reduced to about a quarter of its previous number or size.

def_cn: (美国或加拿大的)25分硬币
def_en: A quarter is an American or Canadian coin that is worth 25 cents.

def_cn: (城镇中某一类人群生活或工作的)区，地区
def_en: A particular quarter of a town is a part of the town where a particular group of people traditionally live or work.

def_cn: (做出反应或行动的)某位人士，某个团体
def_en: To refer to a person or group you may not want to name, you can talk about the reactions or actions from a particular quarter .

def_cn: (军人、水手、仆人的)住处，宿舍，营房
def_en: The rooms provided for soldiers, sailors, or servants to live in are called their quarters .
If people are quartered somewhere, they are provided with accommodation for a short time, usually while they are working away from home.

def_cn: 近距离地;近在咫尺；接近地
def_en: If you do something at close quarters, you do it very near to a particular person or thing.
If you say that someone was given no quarter, you mean that they were not treated kindly by someone who had power or control over them.
